stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on an underground oil-rig area, modeling oil drills and implementing a new enemy ("Fizz Oil") with eye animations, attack states, and a gameplay effect that makes the floor temporarily slippery. He also reports off-stream progress fixing older content (Course 4 and the Zoo), discusses performance/caching considerations, and briefly touches on ROMhack legality and an IP-lawyer counterclaim case.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces and largely completes a new oil-themed enemy with a non-engine-code slippery-surface mechanic, plus notable statements about open-sourcing the engine/codebase and practical constraints (family/finances) shaping project scope.

findings.summary: Kaze says he finished fixing Course 4 off-stream and considers it ready for beta testing; he plans to send it out for testing soon.
findings.quote: Most of what I did off cam was actually fixing up Course 4. I finished fixing up Course 4 so it's ready for beta testing—we're gonna send it off to be tested soon.

findings.summary: The Zoo level has been repaired and is awaiting a few remaining animations from Zeina; Kaze notes that new work often breaks older levels, requiring repeated regression fixes across prior content.
findings.quote: I finished repairing everything in the zoo... all we're waiting now is for a few animations that Zeina's making... whenever we work we're breaking a bunch of old levels so I'm going through them all again and fixing them.

findings.summary: Kaze is exploring a Zoo star-select concept but worries it may conflict with his broader star-select framing that shows Mario traveling to each level.
findings.quote: The idea with the star selects is that it shows Mario traveling to the level... if we have something like that, it's not gonna make much sense.

findings.summary: He adds/iterates an oil-rig underground setpiece: wants denser fog, oil clouds, and drills; he plans to add oil clouds and possibly dead fish for environmental storytelling.
Kaze notes limitations/bugs in Blender visualization due to Fast64 rendering issues; he mentions Fast64 is open source and wishes more contributors were fixing it.
findings.quote: It looks a bit shit in Blender because of a render bug in Fast64... I wish there were more people working on Fast64.

findings.summary: He highlights a major engine-side capacity improvement: switching to hash tables (vs normal geo layouts) increases available geo/model IDs (up to 0x60), giving more space for geometry/content.
findings.quote: That's so freeing that we have hashing tables now instead of normal geo layouts... we can actually have up to model ID 0x60.

findings.summary: A new enemy concept is defined: "Fizz Oil" (oil variant inspired by SM64's electric Fizz Lit). It slithers, then performs a 'swoop' to flatten into a puddle state, supporting sliding gameplay.
findings.quote: Basically... it's going to slime around, and then when it sees Mario, it's going to go whoop... and turn into a puddle... then you can slide on it.

findings.summary: Fizz Oil implementation: Kaze troubleshoots why texture arguments/animation changes were not applying, discovers related function/action sequencing issues, and stabilizes the eye/texture-shift behavior.
findings.quote: The problem is action 4 went to action 0 instead of action 5 this whole time. Well, that explains everything.

findings.summary: He intentionally avoids editing engine code for slipperiness; instead, when Mario is within the enemy’s radius, he finds the floor surface under Mario and temporarily swaps its surface type to a slippery one, backing up and restoring values.
findings.quote: Since we don't want to touch engine code... we store the triangle that Mario is standing on and we just dynamically edit the triangle... once Mario leaves the surface we reset it.

findings.summary: Kaze frames micro-optimizations and cache behavior as meaningful at scale, preferring patterns that avoid extra engine-path work even if per-frame savings seem tiny.
findings.quote: You're gonna waste 0.1 microseconds here... you do this 20 times... on average it's more like 4 microseconds... 4 microseconds is a lot in my world.

findings.summary: He flags a separate planned performance improvement: transposing a scale-table matrix to improve cache behavior; he explicitly defers this refactor to later.
findings.quote: I'm making a note for this... transpose the scale table matrix... terrible for cache cleaning... I'm not doing that right now.

findings.summary: Fizz Oil’s gameplay role is explicitly positioned as 'vibe' plus mild hazard rather than a lethal threat; the danger comes from sliding on stairs into boiling oil. He also plans soap as a counter (killing the enemy) and discusses reward signaling (coins vs implying a star).
findings.quote: They're here for the vibes, you know?... not every enemy has to be like a super obstacle.

findings.summary: Kaze uses the project’s particle engine to prototype oil/boiling effects, comparing it to a 'poverty' Niagara; he shifts away from 'soul/dying' looking particles toward darker smoke-like bubbles for the oil theme.
findings.quote: The particle engine is so useful... it's almost like Niagara... but the absolute poverty version of it.

findings.summary: He discusses ROMhack distribution/legality, noting that with decomp-based projects 'patch' is a legal framing even if most bytes differ. He cites a current case where a ROM hacker hired an IP lawyer and may successfully reverse a YouTube claim, suggesting possible precedent/hope for counterclaims.
findings.quote: He actually hired an IP lawyer... successfully submitted a claim and YouTube's looking at it.

findings.summary: Kaze says making a brand-new N64 game is something he’d like, but it isn’t financially viable because he has a family to provide for, so he must prioritize 'sensible decisions.'
findings.quote: I wish I could, but it's not financially viable... I do have a family now that I need to provide for.

biobak.summary: Biobak is present in chat; Kaze anticipates Biobak’s typical feedback on visual palette and polygon/triangle counts, indicating an ongoing art/perf feedback loop between them.
biobak.quote: There are some polygons I can remove here... before Biobak cusses me out.

zeina.summary: Zeina is producing animations needed to restore functionality in the Zoo level; Kaze also mentions she is out with friends during this stream and earlier takes a call from Zeina’s dad about house information, hinting at ongoing life logistics alongside development.

findings.summary: Lilaa appears in chat; Kaze riffs on a running joke about Lilaa 'dying' (then clarifies it’s a bit), showing the stream’s community tone and how far he’ll take comedic bits before backing off when viewers take them seriously.
findings.quote: I would have kept committing, but the guy actually thought Lilaa died... I can't keep the bit going. That is too mean.

key_stories.title: Implementing the oil enemy "Fizz Oil" and making oil physically slippery
key_stories.summary: Kaze designs an oil variant of SM64’s Fizz Lit that alternates between a crawling state and a flattened puddle 'swoop' state, with animated eyes/texture shifts. The enemy’s main gameplay impact is altering movement by making nearby ground slippery, turning stair-heavy spaces into hazards that can slide Mario into boiling oil.
key_stories.challenge: Create a new enemy with readable states and a meaningful oil-themed mechanic without heavy engine modifications, while also handling animation/texture argument bugs.
key_stories.process: He prototypes the model and eye states, builds a simple state machine (crawl forward → swoop/flatten → crawl back), troubleshoots texture/animation not updating (including a wrong action transition), and implements slipperiness by dynamically editing the surface type of the floor triangle under Mario when within the enemy’s radius (with backup/restore).
key_stories.outcome: Fizz Oil largely works: it animates, pushes Mario, creates localized slippery floors, and is planned to be killable with soap (with coin drops to avoid implying a star reward). Remaining tasks include boiling-oil environmental effects, oil clouds, and polish (e.g., dead fish set dressing).
key_stories.key_quote: Since we don't want to touch engine code... we just dynamically edit the triangle... once Mario leaves the surface we reset it.

key_stories.title: Regression fixing: Course 4 and the Zoo keep breaking as the project evolves
key_stories.summary: Kaze describes a recurring pattern: new work causes older levels to break, forcing him to revisit and repair previously completed content. He reports Course 4 is repaired and ready for beta testing, while the Zoo is repaired but blocked on Zeina’s remaining animations.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining stability across many levels while the engine/content pipeline keeps changing.
key_stories.process: He tests older courses, applies bug fixes found during playtesting, repairs broken level logic/assets, and coordinates with Zeina for missing animations needed to restore full functionality.
key_stories.outcome: Course 4 is declared ready for beta testing; Zoo is near-functional pending animations, with a future decision needed for its star-select presentation.
key_stories.key_quote: Whenever we work we're breaking a bunch of old levels so I'm going through them all again and fixing them.

key_stories.title: Performance philosophy: avoiding engine edits and tracking cache-level optimizations
key_stories.summary: While implementing slipperiness for Fizz Oil, Kaze chooses an approach that avoids engine-code changes to reduce per-frame overhead and keep systems modular. He also notes a separate matrix transpose optimization to improve cache behavior, but defers it.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing new gameplay features with performance budgets and maintainability on N64 constraints.
key_stories.process: He rejects an engine change suggestion, implements a localized runtime surface swap, and records a TODO for a deeper cache-related matrix refactor.
key_stories.outcome: Feature works with minimal engine intrusion; optimization work is tracked for later.
key_stories.key_quote: 4 microseconds is a lot in my world.

key_stories.title: Long-term preservation: committing to open-sourcing the codebase/engine
key_stories.summary: Kaze states a clear intention to open-source the project’s code/engine so it can be maintained after he leaves and used by others to create new hacks on top of his engine work.
key_stories.challenge: Ensuring RTY’s tech doesn’t become unmaintainable or lost to time if the original creator steps away.
key_stories.process: He publicly commits on-stream to open-sourcing and frames it as a deliberate design/legacy goal.
key_stories.outcome: A documented promise that can be revisited in interviews: timing, licensing, what will be included/excluded, and how contributors will be credited.

key_stories.title: Legal climate check: IP-lawyer counterclaim on YouTube as a hopeful precedent
key_stories.summary: Kaze discusses how decomp-based hacks are 'patches' in name but effectively fully changed games, and mentions a ROM hacker who hired an IP lawyer to contest a YouTube claim. He suggests the claim has been forwarded back to the claimant and the video may be restored.
key_stories.challenge: Uncertainty around takedowns and what practical legal defenses exist for ROMhack/decomp communities.
key_stories.process: He relays the reported legal step (hiring an IP lawyer) and YouTube’s current review/forwarding status, framing it as potentially significant news.
key_stories.outcome: Raises a documentary thread: whether formal legal responses can work and how RTY plans to reduce risk (distribution format, messaging, etc.).
key_stories.key_quote: He actually hired an IP lawyer... and YouTube's looking at it.
